Award.AbstractNarration:
The last few years showed a dramatic progress on expander graphs and property 'tau'; these developments led to the 'affine sieve method' showing that for many groups acting on the set of integer lattice points in n-dimensional Euclidean space, each orbit has infinitely many vectors whose entries are all almost primes, i.e., every entry is a product of a bounded number of primes. This is a non-commutative version of classical number theoretic results. We plan to take this direction some steps further and to apply similar methods for developing 'group sieve method' for the study of pure group theoretical problems. This method seems to be suitable for solving problems which are out of reach by the classical group theoretic methods. Applying this method to various groups of important in geometry and topology- e.g., the mapping class group, it is expected to give also some geometric applications. So all together generalized number theoretic methods are expected to have some significant geometric applications.

Groups acting on certain mathematical objects as symmetry is in the heart of mathematical research. Most mathematical and physical questions are modeled as group acting on a certain set. This proposal deals with groups on certain geometric and combinatorial objects and is to study properties of these actions. The topics discussed in this proposal involve connections between several areas of research and illustrate the unity of mathematics and its connection with computer science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Expander graphs have been a focus of interest in computer science in the last four decades. In the last decade it has been shown that they have also various applications in pure mathematics. Most notable is the "affine sieve method" which has been developed by Bourgain, Gamburd and Sarnak and open new horizons in "non-commutative analytic number theory".

   Our work took this method a further step by developing an analogous sieve method to be used in group theory. It addresses questions like " how large is a subset Y  of an infinite  countable group G ? " . Classical methods cannot address such a question since the group G has no natural measure. Our approch studies a random walk on the group and checks how often it fall into Y as a measurement  of its size. The remarkable thing is that by this probabilistic approach we were able to answer questions that have  nothing to do with probability. For example we answered a problem which has been asked in the 90's by  Hrushovski, Kropholler, Lubotzky and  Shalev: a finitely generated linear group in which the proper powers contain a finite index subgroup is virtually solvable. This purely algebraic result has been proven by a combination of combinatorial and probabilistic methods.

    Other notable applications are for the mapping class group and to the theory of 3-manifolds. We used probabilistic methods to show  the existence of 3-manifolds with various properties. There is no known method to prove such results by explicit methods. This is a first step in building Erdos' type random methods within the theory of 3-manifolds. Along the way we established new arithmetic quotients of the mapping class group- a group which is of great importance in geometry and topology. This open a new research area studying the generalized Torelli groups ect, in analoge to the classical work which fasinated mathematicians in the last 100 years. 

   The theory developed combines a good number of sub fields of mathematics and computer science and hence contribute to the interaction between these areas.
